titleStmt.title: Letter from G.W. Gibson to F.L. Frelinghuysen February 19th, 1883

bibl.title: Letter from G.W. Gibson to F.L. Frelinghuysen February 19th, 1883
Notes from Liberian Legation In U.S. to Department of State, 1862-1898 T807

div1.p: Sir I had athe honor to forward you a dispatch last year, asking the consideration of the government of the United States of America to several matters in connection with the welfare and interestes of this Republic.

Having up to the present recieved no acknowledgement of that communication and in view of the fact that our complications in connection with the North West Boundary Question have increased rather than diminished, I begg to enclose a copy herewith fearing that hte original may have miscarried.

I have the honor also to forward you a copy of a Resolution of the Senate of this Republci adopted at its late session touching the question of the North West Boundary which it had under consideration The fact that the government of the United States unsolicited by that of Her Majesty the Queen Great Britain and Ireland and this State to act as umpire on this question, and in case of any disagree-
Hon. F.L. Frelinghuysen Secretary of State For the United States of America

ment on the part of the Commissioners representing the two governments the decision of the United States would be final. I beg to pull your attention to this understanding and to request that your government will be kind enought to give some expression on the subject, so as to set the matter at rest.

I need scarcely mention that this perplexing question has been and still is the source of deep concern to this Republic and a terminatioin of the dispute by the kind intervention of your govern- ment would be hailed with great delight and profound gratitude by the citizens generally.
I have the honor to be your most obedient servant G.W. Gibson
Enclosures 1. Dispatch dated Feby 2. 1882 2. Senate Resolution on Draft convention
